criterion: Provides a detailed description of the importance of regular asthma follow-up visits for a 10-year-old.
Incorrectly states that a 10-year-old can self-manage their asthma without parental supervision.
Asks the user about the child's current medication regimen and any changes made since the last visit.
Uses clear and natural language, explaining the purpose of the follow-up visit and what the child can expect during the appointment.
Incorrectly suggests that the child's asthma is under control and does not need further monitoring.
Provides instructions on how to use the child's inhaler correctly and when to take medication.
Does not address potential concerns or questions the user may have about their child's asthma treatment.
Mentions the importance of keeping track of the child's asthma action plan and when to seek emergency medical help.
Incorrectly states that a peak flow meter is not necessary for a 10-year-old with mild asthma.
Asks the user about any changes in the child's symptoms or medication side effects since the last visit.
Provides reassurance that the child's asthma is being well-managed and that the child is at low risk of complications.
Incorrectly suggests that the child's asthma is not a chronic condition and that they will outgrow it.
